thread.title: Devon's Ambrosia factory will not close if it can't be sold, bosses say - Devon Live

author: Hannah Finch
title: Devon's Ambrosia factory will not close if it can't be sold, bosses say - Devon Live
text:
Devon's Ambrosia factory will not close if it can't be sold, bosses say Ambrosia custard is 100 years-old and is part of Devon's heritage Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
It is business as usual for 300 staff at the Ambrosia custard factory, bosses have said.
The custard and rice pudding brand, which celebrated its centenary last year, is set to be put on the market by parent company Premier Foods .
But it has insisted that the factory in Lifton will not close. Ambrosia is part of Devon's heritage Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
A spokesman said: “It is business as usual for the 300 people.
"The search for a buyer has just started and there’s no guarantee that a sale will take place.”
However, he said that the factory will ‘100 per cent not be closed'.
Take a look inside the Ambrosia factory in the video below Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
He said: “Premier will keep it. It’s a great business but they think it can be more valuable to someone else with resources to invest in it.
“Any buyer would be looking to grow the business and would therefore need the people.”
Premier Foods announced on Tuesday that it was looking to sell the brand .
It had seen lower sales of custard products because of the hot summer and had reduced its promotional investment in the brand. Read More
Premier Foods has owned the business since 2003 and invested £58million into the brand.
It makes 250million tins and pots of custard and rice pudding, tapioca and semolina per year. History of Devon's Ambrosia
1917: The creamery was founded by Albert Morris in Lifton. Named Ambrosia, which means 'food from the gods' he employed around a dozen locals to make rich food for infants. He took milk from local farms where most of the cows were the Red Ruby breed, and dried it with roller dryers.
1936: The Creamery passes to Albert's his son Oscar Morris after his death.
WWII: Ambrosia sent dried milk to help feed children at the time of milk rationing and when many mothers were working in factories to support the war effort. Creamed Rice was included in Red Cross Prisoner of War parcels, with several recipients writing after the war to say they 'owed their lives to it'.
1956: Oscar Morris retired and sold his controlling interest in the company to Virol Ltd, whose parent company was Bovril Ltd.
1957: Ambrosia could afford to advertise for the first time and due to increasing demand, the creamery opened a new factory near to the original production facility in Lifton.
1961: Ambrosia launched the first canned Devon Custard, made on the canning lines in Lifton. By the early 1970s, following investment in the latest canning technology, the quality of Ambrosia Devon Custard is further improved and Ambrosia becomes the brand leader in 'ready-to-serve' custard.
One of Ambrosia's main selling points is the fact its made in Devon using local milk, later to become immortalised in the advertising slogan 'Devon knows how they make it so creamy'
1990: the entire company was acquired by Colman's Ltd., a famous brand of mustard.
2001: Bought out by Unilever
2004: Unilever sold the brand on to Premier Foods, which also owns the Bisto, Branston and Hovis brands.
It exports to Ireland, Canada and USA and has annual sales of about £90million.
But it needs more investment which others will be better able to make, said a spokesman.
Premier will use the proceeds from any sale to accelerate its strategy and invest in some of its other businesses and pay debt.
It was announced on Tuesday that chief executive Gavin Darby will step down on January 31.
Mr Darby's departure will end a six-year tenure at the group and comes after a public row with activist investor Oasis Management, which claimed he has presided over years of value destruction. Read More Barden factory closure: Warning more companies could leave Plymouth in Brexit fear
On the sale of Ambrosia, Mr Darby said: "The board has determined that it should focus resources on areas of the business which have the best potential for growth through accelerated investment in consumer marketing and high return capital projects.
"Accordingly, we are pursuing options to fund these plans as well as delivering a meaningful reduction in net debt, through discussions with third parties regarding the potential disposal of our Ambrosia brand. Read More
